title: Monday, 19th March, 2018
bodyHTML:
rise2010 Morning
11:03 am
BE11:04am

Hey, hello, welcome, hi there.

Soundbuy Morning
Miss Piggy EU agrees on two-year Brexit transition deal https://www.marketwatch.com/story/eu-agrees-on-two-year-brexit-transition-deal-2018-03-19?mod=bnbh
BE11:04am

Start here, I guess.

BE11:04am

rise2010 Micro Focus in focus this morning
Nately Wow MCRO - that bad?
Otter Hello friends. Today I would like to hear about Accrol blowing up again please
#REF! hello? I wonder if the left will find anything to talk about...
Miss Piggy Facebook om the left.
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Facebook, pre-market US.

rise2010 Had to get the pun in there
#REF! that's... not a very big fall tbh, see what happens in full market
BE11:05am

Currently the second-most traded stock in premarket, though note that's still only 59k .......

BE11:05am

.......... and down 3.6% live-ish.

#REF! interesting aspect for Facebook. If this had happened next month and ruled a breach... EU can levy fines of up to 10% revenue under GDPR
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Why? Well ........... Kinda noisy this weekend!

RA hey kids
vonB Anything on Henkel Q1 please?
Mouselet Good morning assorted people
BE11:07am

The story, at its core, seems to be that a market research company breached Facebook's T&Cs.

BE11:07am

Which is exciting!

RA is it because facebook helped putin get elected?
Mouselet It sounds as if someone has found one of the umpteen zillion dubious things that Facebook has done that might actually be illegal under actual law
Miss Piggy Facebook US Election probe @RA
11:07 am
BE11:08am

And how much you want to roll that fact into a conspiracy theory depends on your appetite for this stuff.

GBKrona hola
Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous and assorted people
BE11:09am

Worth re-reading this Gillian Tett column from a few months ago, BTW: https://www.ft.com...-9e4f-7f5e6a7c98a2

Mouselet Oh dear MicroFocus
Mouselet who would have thought Autonomy might turn out to poison everything it touches
BE11:09am

But anyway, here's the bit of the story I don't quite get. And because you know everything, ROTR, you might be able to help.

Miss Piggy ... the widom of rabbles ...
Soundbuy The ROTR collective brain.......
Miss Piggy *wisdom* even
11:10 am
BE11:10am

I still don't have a sense here of how political forces used the CA data malevolently.

luzh What I don't understand is how populist demagogue strongmen ever managed to gain power before social media came along.
luzh It's almost as though there's something... popular .. about them
BE11:11am

Which is weird, because surely if they did some people must've seen it. What's the point of propaganda if no-one sees it?

Miss Piggy @BE: they get to know which buttons to press. how to get you hot under the collar.
BE11:11am

So far, we have an an investigation of a suspected murder that hasn't identified a weapon and only has a vague idea about the corpse.

Mouselet Propaganda seen only by the people who are responsive to it is exactly what you want ...
11:12 am
BE11:12am

When I've asked this elsewhere, folk have mentioned this kind of thing .....

BE11:12am

https://twitter.com/podehaye/status/975649697284141056

BE11:12am

.... Okay, sure. But how?

red the facts are facebook collects data. lets say you trust facebook but what happens if a third party gets the data.
soldsoldsupersold now to the most important thing, MCRO...
11:13 am
BE11:13am

How do you game FV's algo?

BE11:14am

Because if the answer is, you "build a list of influencers and try to target them specifically" .... well, that's the job desc of every other person in Hackney.

Miss Piggy @BE: haven't you commented on this in the past on the left, you and Murphy talking about how social media makes people live in their own self-selecting bubble.
Lemmy there's a lot of FB targeting that only the targeted get to see, everyone else is blissfully ignorant of it
BE11:14am

Anyway. Let's get on with the important stuff.

11:14 am
undefined
red imo 95% of social media users are wasting their time. but that i suppose depends on your definition of using time productively
BE11:15am

(@Miss Piggy: yes, probably. You shouldn't expect consistency here. It's just typing.)

Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 846.60, down 1 (-55.08%), High: 1,199, Low: 782.20, Volume: 7.75m
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Welcome back, Autonomy! We missed you!

BE11:16am

So ....... licence sales are terrible!

BE11:16am

Like, down 20% terrible.

luzh The social science evidence repeatedly shows that social media has a small depolarising effect e.g. https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/1369118X.2018.1444783
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Which was the kind of number HP Enterprise was printing pre the Micro Focus merger, and all the analysts said, "oh that's just transition uncertainty stuff wait until the new management gets in there and sorts things out they have an excellent track record ...."

BE11:17am

Turns out .... nah.

BE11:18am

The biggest bit of this warning, gloriously, is that Micro Focus seems to have stuffed up a software installation.

Blank canvas morning
Miss Piggy @luzh: I scrolled to the conclusion, thanks.
Bonnemort Down 1 and that's 55%? Shome mishtake surely?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Rejigging the sales force's legacy IT system has been hugely disruptive to the business. The business being Micro Focus. A business that made its name making sure legacy IT system rejigs are not hugely disruptive to the business.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian LOL
BE11:20am

So. CEO gone “to spend more time with his family and pursue another opportunity”.

BE11:20am

Stephen Murdoch, who ran core Micro Focus pre merger, dropped in.

red yes often the case when they see a long hard slog in front of them, better to hide away and come back after folks have forgotten.
11:21 am
BE11:21am

(@Bonnemort: Oh. Add it to the list of things that don't work. It's a long list.)

BE11:22am

But long term, everything's still on track ......

BE11:22am

Despite the integration challenges, the Board believes that the
fundamental thesis of the HPE Software acquisition remains intact. Micro Focus’ strategy, dividend policy, leverage target and Return of Value approach remain unchanged.

#REF! @BE did the FT get Micro Focus in to rejig your live pricing info :)
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Which seems to mean, "it wasn't our baseline scenario for HPE to be a basket case, but it was the bear case so now we're going to hit the bear case."

DJ Micro battling with Accrol for faller of the day
BE11:23am

Have Goldman.

BE11:24am

Micro Focus revised FY18 guidance for topline growth to decline 6%-9% from a decline of 2%-4%, mainly driven by weakness in licenses. We note that this is mostly the bear thesis playing out, the one we highlighted in our note Balancing legacy roll-off & execution risks vs. balance sheet optionality; initiate at Neutral (published December 12, 2017), with HPE integration issues resulting in steeper topline declines given higher salesforce attrition in HPE.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

We had also highlighted the importance of management in terms of delivery of the cost synergies, and believe that CEO Chris Hsu stepping down is likely to be taken negatively by investors, as he was key to integration of the combined entity in our view.

BE11:25am

And Numis.

BE11:25am

Management characterises the issues as largely "transitional" from the HPE combination; whilst we concur with the logic, we note that guidance effectively calls the bottom in the current period and implies a good H2 recovery with a -3 to -6% performance. As a result our new forecasts are set at the bottom of the guidance range. From a valuation perspective, this performance will clearly restart the "terminal multiple" debate and our lower TP reflects an element of this, moving our long-term target FCF multiple to 7.5% from 6.4%.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Management believes fundamental thesis of HPE deal is intact, albeit it may be a "good deal" rather than a "great deal". Stress-testing pre acquisition was based on a substantially worse scenario than is currently playing out.

Nately Accrol is toilet paper.
BE11:26am

And Investec.

BE11:27am

We still maintain our concerns over top line declines being greater than expected, now into FY19, and the requirement for
greater cost reductions than expected, which would further destabilise the top line outlook. Having spoken to management,
they are confident there are no issues on the covenant with the revolver not yet drawn down. We place our forecasts and TP
under review, but retain our cautious stance.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

That "cautious stance" was "sell", btw.

undefined
Miss Piggy @Nately: yes, http://www.accrol.co.uk/
BE11:28am

And then there's Hammerson.

11:28 am
Hammerson PLC (HMSO:LSE): Last: 541.60, up 104.5 (+23.91%), High: 560.00, Low: 538.20, Volume: 33.95m
BE11:29am

Clean Sunday-for-Monday scoop from The Times. https://www.thetim...ammerson-hh3mgn9qp

Forester Accrol - has to be my worst investment ever! Ironically it was supposed to be a safe, boring one with no threat of digitalisation!
BE11:30am

Don't see those much any more, and huge congratulations to Deirdre Hipwell for landing it.

hornblower Mothercare down another 15% today, market cap now only £25m
red bid for hammerson brave at best, short sighted at worst imo
Otter @Forester I have heard that many older private investors bought it for similar reasons. It is sad that they may have lost money.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

So ..... the upshot here is that Klépierre offered a 41% premium and Hammerson told them to sod off pretty much immediately.

red you wonder if hammerson board doing a mothercare here.
BE11:31am

Because they'd rather pursue the merger with Intu that can only dilute all the reasons they gave for rejecting -- the quality portfolio and all that.

red hammersons strength even after intu is europe which isnt as saturated as uk, but still its going to get there soon.
BE11:32am

Amazingly, 615p/share (on 8 March 2018) is still a 22% discount to spot NAV, which is an indication of how much folk dislike the Intu deal.

red intu is uk centric isnt it
madrugada Luzh: have you ever heard of Hitler?
11:33 am
BE11:33am

This, also, is very much Klépierre's strategy. It's predatory when its competitors look weak and vulnerable.

BE11:34am

Robert Duncan at Numis has a handy history.

BE11:34am

Klepierre has form in this regard, having acquired distressed Dutch mall landlord Corio in 2014 which also resulted in Simon Property Group (SPG), the largest US mall REIT, having a c.20% holding in Klepierre; SPG has long had ambitions to enter the UK market having launched an unsuccessful bid for INTU (CSCG as it was at the time) in late-2011 and from which it was forced to walk away.

MonkeyTrader Is Klepierre versus Hammerson really about David Simon v John Whittaker? Simon now chairman of Klepierre....tried to bust up Whittaker's last deal and lost.
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Now, where it gets tricky is how we read the share price moves.

red in this case i think the assets look vulnerable.
BE11:36am

Hammerson's up and stuck, which seems to suggest an expectation that Klepierre will be back, possibly even by going hostile I guess.

Blank canvas any update on Smurfit Kappa and Int Paper? No holding, just curious.
red i would stay well away from office and retail centres. i suspect you will be able to buy much lower.
Forester @otter Absolutely! Brings the whole IPO process into disrepute in my opinion
BE11:36am

But Intu's also up, which seems ............. odd? If we're assuming Hammerson's now in play, why would Intu be up?

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Back to Numis.

BE11:37am

When HMSO announced its intention to acquire INTU on 6 December, we highlighted the potential for Klepierre to seek to disrupt the party; based on the pricing level, we would expect HMSO shares to rally this morning, but given HMSO mgmt has summarily rejected the offer, we would expect the shares to again come under downward pressure following any bounce. The fixed nature of the HMSO/INTU merger ratio (0.475 HMSO shares for every 1 INTU share), makes the initial INTU share price reaction harder to call. If HMSO's share price rally is sustained, that would imply the market believes the Klepierre bid could be successful and thus INTU's shares should drop as it moves back to being appraised on a stand-alone, as-is basis. However, if the market holds little stock by a Klepierre/HMSO tie-up, then INTU's share price response should be more aligned to HMSO

BE11:38am

@Monkeytrader already notes the personality history here ....

RA @BE can you give an opinion on Glencore in the dawn of a 'trade war'?
GBKrona @BE - might Klepierre go for just INTU if HMSO not possible?
Otter @Forester is it possible for the NomAd to get into trouble?
11:38 am
BE11:38am

As in, Klepierre's 20% owned by Simon Property, whose CEO David Simon is also chairman of Klepierre's supervisory board.

Groundhog Day @BE for later, I'd also be interested if you have any idea on Smurfit and the "deafening silence"... Usually I read that as something going on no? Thanks
BE11:39am

Peel Hunt incoming.

BE11:39am

Despite the Board rejection, Hammerson is now in play and the likelihood of its proposed merger with Intu Properties proceeding has decreased considerably. This is likely to be reflected in the relative performance of both share prices.

For Hammerson, the proposal set out today by Klépierre implies a discount of 21% to Hammerson’s NAV, and a discount of c13% to gross assets. In our view, the appetite among shareholder’s to accept such an offer would be more balanced than the quick rebuttal by Hammerson’s Board would suggest given UK retain headwinds and persistent concerns around the valuation of prime UK retail assets.

wayneJ @BE - I thought Simon had coveted HMSO for a long time. This is a very elegant way for Simon to take control - 'Breton Pulleys' comes to mind.
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Incidentally, if you want a definition of "living lucky," there's Exane, which upgraded both Hammerson and Intu this morning.

BE11:40am

Nothing whatsoever to do with the bid. And they still hate the merger. But ......

Soundbuy @ Blank canvas - don't reckon IP will walk........though depends where Smurfit see fair value.......even now valuation none too far from SMDS or Mondi..........
madrugada BE: the Sunday Times did run an article on the bookies claiming the limit on fobs would be cut to 2 quid. Their source being a conversation with a friend of the Culture Secretary. It's so easy to manipulate a story. I never believed that the government would be in favour of such a large reduction as it would reducing tax revenue.
BE11:41am

Our argument is simple; (1) The combined Hammerson/Intu business is too cheap if the acquisition completes and (2) there is further upside for Hammerson in the unlikely event of the Intu bid falling away.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

So .....

BE11:42am

Should Hammerson acquire Intu? No
We have never been fans of Hammerson acquiring Intu on the proposed terms. The acquisition increases UK exposure on the cusp of a downturn in shopping centre values and further increases leverage for an already stretched balance sheet. We give credit to more than GBP 40m of cost synergies vs company guidance for GBP 25m. However, Intu still reduces our Hammerson valuation by c.9%.
Will the offer succeed in any case? It is highly likely
We estimate c.50% overlap between the Hammerson and Intu share registers excluding index funds. For Intu shareholders, the combined entity is almost certainly preferable to a standalone Intu, particularly after synergies. Other Hammerson shareholders may see consolidation as a necessary step in tackling the challenge from online. The Intu share price already attaches a nearly 100% probability to deal succeeding, which feels correct in our view

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

And to bookmakers .........

BE11:43am

@madrugada mentions that the reporting around this has added, rather than removed, fog.

Blank canvas Soundbuy: I read somewhere Smurfit would start talking at 40 euros. Can't imagine IP would go for that.
BE11:44am

Today, though, we get an actual first-hand source rather than an off-the-record briefing in the Red Lion.

Groundhog Day Blank Canvas - how would IP not go for that? 10% increase from their initial offer would seem like a reasonable bump. Nobody expects the first offer to work?!?
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Gambling Commission wants "£30 or less" per spin.

BE11:46am

Along with a bunch of blah-blah measures about deterring problem gamblers feeding the machines, which the market has quite rightly dismissed as irrelevant.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 334.30, up 13.8 (+4.31%), High: 337.90, Low: 330.10, Volume: 3.13m
11:46 am
Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 173.90, up 3.45 (+2.02%), High: 182.00, Low: 173.05, Volume: 10.45m
Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 7,640, up 5 (+0.07%), High: 7,685, Low: 7,610, Volume: 23.57k
BE11:46am

Who can summarise here? Canaccord can.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

The Gambling Commission this morning published its advice to the government on the Triennial review of gambling machines, and this looks like a positive outcome for the industry (relative to previous expectations). The GC has recommended a reduction in maximum stakes on non-slots B2 content (90% of B2 revenues) from £100 to "no greater than £30". It recommends that B2 slots (10% of B2 revenues) see max stakes reduced to £2. It also recommends a trial on "tracked play", where players would have to pre-register, across all B1, B2 and B3 machines.

BE11:47am

This would definitely be viewed as a positive outcome for the retail betting industry, given recent newspaper reports suggesting that the new head of the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) was in favour of max stakes coming down to £2 for all B2 content. Clearly, the government does not have to follow the regulator's advice, but it would be unlikely to take a significantly contrarian view. We would still see the most likely outcome as a reduction in max stakes on non-slots B2 content (almost entirely roulette) to £20; reflecting the lower max stakes on slots, that would point to a blended max stake cut from £100 to £18.40. Harder to predict is the impact of "tracked play", which if introduced on all FOBT content would also have a detrimental impact on revenues.

BE11:48am

Ladbrokes is now just an option on the GVC kicker, of course.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Ladbrokes Coral was previously pricing in close to a worst case scenario - its share price was 3p above the 167p GVC offer price; but in the case of a max £20 stake, shareholders receive a CVR worth 30p. The GC recommendation points to a CVR value potentially a little lower (to reflect the lower slots stakes and impact of tracked play). The GVC offer had implicitly estimated the LCL Ebitda impact of a £2 max stake at £140m, reducing to a £97m hit at £20 - in both cases, after taking mitigating actions (ie shop closures). The WMH impact would be c.45% lower.

BE11:48am

We would view this as positive news for both LCL (Buy, TP 218p) and WMH (Buy, TP 375p). GVC (Buy, TP 1070p) is relatively insulated from the Triennial outcome, but a smaller reduction in maximum stakes would also be valuation accretive for GVC.

Soundbuy @ Blank canvas - the 'geographical fit' for one and the desire for IP to increase exposure to graphic packaging - agree with GD above .....
Blank canvas Groundhog Day: 40 would have to become 45 or 50 euros, which becomes very expensive
BE11:49am

We've tonnes of stuff in the archive about what the various stake limits would mean for earnings so refer to that if you're really interested.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Instead, I just wanted to highlight this interesting bit that came out of the JD Wetherspoon analyst meet on Friday.

BE11:50am

[Slot] machines generate 2.5% of sales, but almost a quarter of PBT, we estimate.

BE11:51am

That's Peel Hunt doing the estimating.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The first meaningful rise in machine income since 2010 is attributed to new digital machines and rising bar sales. The new digital machines are more expensive, but get more use. They take about six weeks to bed in and do not work in every location. As machines are leased and have no associated labour, debt or central cost, we estimate their profit equated to 24% of PBT in H1. Thus, we believe the recovery in machine sales explains why H1 was ahead.

Groundhog Day Don't think so. If someone talks at 40 EURs, that means they are willing to sell there. So DD would maybe add 1 EUR. But not more.
BE11:51am

Which is interesting, right? Just under a quarter of JDW's earnings (estimated) come from puggies.

BE11:52am

Meaning fixed-odds betting terminals are a bigger proportion of group earnings for JD Wetherspoon than they are for Paddy Power Betfair.

Blank canvas I'm just a spectator in this: sold my holding a long time ago, so will cheer the winner whoever it is
11:53 am
BE11:53am

(And, yes, I know all about B2 and B3/4 machine licencing don't @ me.)

undefined
Forester Ironically, when I first invested in JDW it precisely because they did not have music, puggies or live sports! But hey ho, my local Spoons was rammed from 9am Friday to 9pm Sunday this weekend so must be doing something right!
Soundbuy @Forester - Beerfest on I believe...
Miss Piggy @BE: shouldn't that be 'don't get @ me'
alewis2005 would have been a good weekend for the pubs with the 6 nations and all
BE11:56am

@Soundbuy: not sure we've a reason to read the silence around Smurfit in any direction.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Because Smurfit's Irish domiciled, there's no automatic PUSU.

Forester @soundbuy Gold cup, rugby etc. My 18yo came home (eventually) in one of those silly Guinness hats
Forester ...and he hates rugby, guinness and racing!
jaws EU deal talks live
Miss Piggy Anyone else in 'BlackRock Frontiers Investment Trust'?
BE11:58am

Smurfit would need to put in a request to the Irish takeover panel to impose a PUSU, which as far as I know hasn't happened.

Soundbuy Cheers
cracklenpop @BE extraordinary stats re JDW - wonder how much in-pub gambling is 'on impulse'? At least bookies are 'dry'.
BE11:59am

Meaning International Paper can take as long as it likes, including going pens down if it wished.

Otter Maybe there is still a little time to comment on our toilet friends the Accrol
11:59 am
BE11:59am

But to be clear, we haven't heard anything any direction on it.

undefined
Miss Piggy Accrol flushes investors down the pan.
wayneJ Any colour on Barclays? Activist alert?
Forester @otter trying to forget about that one. Can't even paper my downstairs khazi with their share certificates in this digital age!
BE12:00pm

Oh. Barclays. Yeah, of course.

11:59 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 217.70, up 8.2 (+3.91%), High: 218.80, Low: 213.80, Volume: 33.89m
BE12:00pm

Sherborne parks its tanks with nearly 5.2% of voting.

BE12:01pm

What's the angle? Dunno. IB spinoff, you'd guess?

GBKrona UK/EU transition deal: "We were able to agree on a large part of what will make up an international agreement for an ordered withdrawal of the UK."
wayneJ Did not F&C lose a major southern european client when Sherborne came along....
wayneJ Wonder if Barclays / Barcap has any change of control clauses?
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Most of the stuff we've been talking about lately with regards Barclays is on the costs-to-match-revenues side, though IB was a bit better than expected last quarter.

wayneJ Also just wondering how many changes of strategy did F&C have under Sherborne. Willl the FCA allow Sherborne control without perhaps knowing the strategy _beforehand_?
BE12:04pm

Anyway, I've absolutely no idea. Martin Arnold does though, and here's his story: https://www.ft.com...-9b4b-bc4b9f08f381

rise2010 Barclays has unperformed needs a prod good move for long term sufferers?
undefined
12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Thought midday and haven't mentioned the Accrol warning.

Accrol Group Holdings PLC (ACRL:LSE): Last: 28.00, no change, Volume: 0.00
BE12:05pm

Hooray for the autopricer! It's actually down 58%.

Blank canvas thanks for views on smurfit from both sides of the page
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Cost inflation seems to have sneaked up on management, in spite of them also being the cause of the October warning.

pfd elderly aunt was advised to buy AIM stocks for the IHT benefit. Glad I put her off and into Fundsmith instead.
Penny Acrol, maker of toilet roll. Possibly the worst IPO of 2016..?
BE12:07pm

I guess they snuck up on Sales Director Gary Earle, who flogged a load of stock in February.

BE12:08pm

https://www.invest...1802151755480666F/

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

https://www.invest...1802151755480666F/

BE12:08pm

https://www.invest...1802130700046546E/

12:09 pm

Zeus Capital is acting as Nominated Adviser and Sole Broker to Accrol Group Holdings plc (Ticker: ACRL.L) on its AIM IPO with a market capitalisation of £93m and £63.5m fundraising

BE12:09pm

Oh yeah. http://zeuscapital...63-5m-fundraising/

BE12:09pm

Anyway. Let's knock off for Monday and get on with something useful.

Miss Piggy bye
Soundbuy Cheers.........
LJ thanks all
pfd better to pay tax on assets than punt assets away
GBKrona thanks @BE, ROTR
12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Thanks for all the comments. Back tomorrow, usual time and usual junk. Afternoon all.
